content.title: ERCP Procedure
content.summary: Therapeutic endoscopic procedure combining upper endoscopy with fluoroscopy to access and treat diseases of the biliary and pancreatic ducts, with sphincterotomy, stone extraction, and stenting as primary interventions
key_points: ERCP is primarily therapeutic, not diagnostic (MRCP for diagnosis)
Key indications: choledocholithiasis, malignant biliary obstruction, bile duct strictures
Sphincterotomy enables stone extraction and stent placement
Post-ERCP pancreatitis is most common complication (3-10%)
Rectal indomethacin and pancreatic stent reduce PEP risk
Bleeding, perforation, cholangitis are other serious complications
Performed under deep sedation or general anesthesia

statement.text: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a combined endoscopic and fluoroscopic procedure used primarily for therapeutic intervention on the biliary and pancreatic ducts. A side-viewing duodenoscope allows cannulation of the ampulla of Vater, contrast injection for imaging, and therapeutic maneuvers including sphincterotomy, stone extraction, and stent placement. Post-ERCP pancreatitis is the most common complication, mitigated by rectal indomethacin and prophylactic pancreatic duct stenting in high-risk patients.
statement.formal: ERCP = Side-viewing duodenoscope + Ampulla cannulation + Fluoroscopy + Therapeutic intervention (sphincterotomy, stone extraction, stenting)

explanation.intuition: Think of ERCP as keyhole surgery for the bile and pancreas ducts. A special scope goes down to the duodenum where the ducts empty. The operator cannulates the tiny opening (ampulla), injects dye to see the ducts on X-ray, then can cut the sphincter open, pull out stones, or place stents to relieve blockages—all without making surgical incisions.
explanation.key_insight: ERCP has largely transitioned from a diagnostic to a therapeutic procedure. MRCP and EUS now provide superior diagnostic imaging without the risks of ERCP. Reserve ERCP for patients who need intervention—not just to 'see what's going on.'
explanation.technical_details: Equipment: side-viewing duodenoscope (vs. forward-viewing EGD scope), sphincterotome, guidewires, extraction balloons/baskets, stents. Technique: identify ampulla → selective cannulation of bile or pancreatic duct → contrast injection → cholangiogram/pancreatogram → therapeutic intervention. Wire-guided cannulation reduces post-ERCP pancreatitis risk. Precut sphincterotomy for difficult access increases complications but enables access.

definitions_glossary.ercp: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography—endoscopic procedure for biliary/pancreatic duct access
definitions_glossary.sphincterotomy: Incision of sphincter of Oddi to enlarge the bile duct opening
definitions_glossary.choledocholithiasis: Stones in the common bile duct—primary indication for ERCP
definitions_glossary.biliary_stent: Plastic or metal tube placed to maintain duct patency
definitions_glossary.ampulla_of_vater: Junction where bile and pancreatic ducts enter the duodenum
definitions_glossary.sphincter_of_oddi: Muscular valve controlling bile and pancreatic juice release
definitions_glossary.post_ercp_pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis occurring after ERCP—most common complication
definitions_glossary.pancreatic_stent: Prophylactic stent placed to prevent post-ERCP pancreatitis
definitions_glossary.cholangiogram: X-ray image of bile ducts after contrast injection
definitions_glossary.cannulation: Insertion of catheter into the ampulla to access ducts
definitions_glossary.extraction_balloon: Balloon catheter used to sweep stones from bile duct
definitions_glossary.precut_sphincterotomy: Cutting before standard cannulation when access is difficult

pathophysiology.mechanism: ERCP provides access to the biliopancreatic ductal system through the natural orifice of the ampulla. Cannulation introduces catheters and guidewires into the desired duct. Sphincterotomy uses electrocautery to cut the sphincter muscle, widening the opening. This enables passage of extraction devices for stone removal or insertion of stents for strictures and obstruction. Post-ERCP pancreatitis results from papillary trauma, contrast injection into pancreatic duct, or thermal injury.

patient_selection.pre_procedural_imaging: MRCP or EUS should confirm indication before ERCP
patient_selection.consent: Discuss risks: pancreatitis (3-10%), bleeding (1%), perforation (<1%), cholangitis (1%)
patient_selection.contraindications: Absolute: patient refusal, inability to tolerate sedation/anesthesia. Relative: coagulopathy, altered anatomy (Roux-en-Y)

procedure_steps: Advance duodenoscope to second portion of duodenum
Cannulate desired duct (bile or pancreatic) with guidewire-assisted technique
Place prophylactic pancreatic stent if high-risk for PEP

sphincterotomy.technique: Electrocautery incision of sphincter in 11-12 o'clock direction
sphincterotomy.indication: Needed for stone extraction, large stent placement

stone_extraction.technique: Extraction balloon or basket to sweep stones from CBD
stone_extraction.large_stones: Mechanical lithotripsy, cholangioscopy with laser lithotripsy

stenting.plastic_stents: Short-term use; require exchange every 3 months
stenting.metal_stents: Longer patency; used for malignant obstruction (covered vs. uncovered)
stenting.indication: Malignant obstruction, benign strictures, bile leaks

post_ercp_pancreatitis.rectal_indomethacin: 100 mg PR immediately before or after procedure
post_ercp_pancreatitis.pancreatic_stent: Prophylactic 5F stent in high-risk patients (SOD, difficult cannulation)

bleeding.prevention: Correct coagulopathy, hold anticoagulants (per ASGE guidelines)

cholangitis.prevention: Ensure adequate drainage; avoid contrast injection without drainage plan

definition.@value: Endoscopic procedure combining upper endoscopy with fluoroscopy for therapeutic access to the biliary and pancreatic ducts

skos.scopeNote: Covers indications, technique, therapeutic interventions, and complication prevention including post-ERCP pancreatitis prophylaxis
skos.example: A 55-year-old with choledocholithiasis on MRCP undergoes ERCP with sphincterotomy and balloon extraction of three bile duct stones

learning_objectives: Select appropriate indications for ERCP vs. MRCP/EUS
Describe the technical steps of ERCP
Apply evidence-based prevention strategies for complications
Compare plastic vs. metal stent applications
clinical_pearls: MRCP first, ERCP when intervention is planned—diagnostic ERCP is obsolete
Rectal indomethacin should be given to ALL patients without contraindications
Pancreatic stent: place in high-risk patients (difficult cannulation, SOD, prior PEP)
Aggressive IV hydration (LR) during and after ERCP reduces PEP risk
Covered metal stents for malignant distal CBD strictures; uncovered for hilar
Duodenoscope-associated infections: ensure proper reprocessing protocols

board_yield.internal_medicine_boards: Moderate - when to refer, complication recognition
board_yield.gastroenterology_boards: Very High - technique, indications, complication management

common_misconceptions: ERCP is primarily diagnostic (false—MRCP/EUS for diagnosis; ERCP for therapy)
Post-ERCP pancreatitis is rare and mild (false—3-10% incidence; can be severe)
All patients need prophylactic antibiotics (false—only if incomplete drainage expected)
